results.snippet: WASHINGTON The 1984 campaign for control of    the U.S. Senate may well have   been decided before it began, by men who didn't run: Democratic Governors Chuck Robb of Virginia, Richard Lamm of Colorado, Richard Riley of South Carolina, Joseph...
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON The 1984 campaign for control of the U.S. Senate may well have been decided before it began, by men who didn't run: Democratic Governors Chuck Robb of Virginia, Richard Lamm of Colorado, Richard Riley of South Carolina, Joseph Brennan of Maine and Ed Herschler of Wyoming. All might have won Republican seats; two or three certainly would have. Without them in the field, all five seats at stake, hence the Senate majority, are likely to remain Republican. My more or less informed guess - based on conversations with Republican, Democratic and nonpartisan analysts - is that the Democrats will gain a net of three, perhaps four seats. But they need to pick up six, or five in the event Geraldine Ferraro becomes Vice President and presiding officer of the Senate. She could then vote to break ties in favor of the Democrats.

headline.main: EX-MICHIGAN ASTRONAUT FACES G.O.P. TEST TODAY

results.snippet: When Jack R. Lousma, one of the two men contending Tuesday for the Republican nomination for the Senate from Michigan, is asked to do a microphone test, he usually responds with a countdown: ''five, four, three, two, one.''    The gesture is a...
results.lead_paragraph: When Jack R. Lousma, one of the two men contending Tuesday for the Republican nomination for the Senate from Michigan, is asked to do a microphone test, he usually responds with a countdown: ''five, four, three, two, one.'' The gesture is a reminder that Mr. Lousma is a former astronaut who was a member of the second crew to occupy the Skylab space station in 1973 and spent more than 11 hours hours outskide the Skylab in two separate space walks. He also commanded the third flight of the space shuttle Columbia in March 1982. Mr. Lousma is locked in what appears to be a tight race with James Dunn, who served one term in the House of Representatives from the Lansing area. A recent poll conducted for The Detroit Free Press showed Mr. Dunn leading Mr. Lousma, 34 percent to 30 percent, among people who said they planned to vote in the primary.However, an undecided category of 36 percent seemed to suggest that neither man had succeeded in arousing great public interest.

headline.main: FORMER ASTRONAUT WINS REPUBLICAN SENATORIAL PRIMARY IN MICHIGAN

results.snippet: Jack R. Lousma, a former astronaut, won the Michigan Republican senatorial primary today, holding a wide margin over James Dunn, a former Congressman.    With 1,251 of the state's 6,630 precincts reporting, Mr. Lousma had 77,508 votes, or 66...
results.lead_paragraph: Jack R. Lousma, a former astronaut, won the Michigan Republican senatorial primary today, holding a wide margin over James Dunn, a former Congressman. With 1,251 of the state's 6,630 precincts reporting, Mr. Lousma had 77,508 votes, or 66 percent, to 39,430 votes, or 34 percent, for Mr. Dunn. Voter turnout was light, with state officials estimating that no more than one-fourth of those eligible to vote in the Republican primary would turn out. Political analysts said a light turnout would tend to favor Mr. Lousma, who has a better financed organization and the endorsement of most of the leading Republican politicians in Michigan.

headline.main: PARTY LINES CLEAR IN MICHIGAN SENATE RACE

results.snippet: A clear ideological confrontation in Michigan this fall was assured Tuesday when Jack R. Lousma, a former astronaut, won the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Carl Levin, a liberal Democrat.     Mr. Lousma, a conservative, defeated former...
results.lead_paragraph: A clear ideological confrontation in Michigan this fall was assured Tuesday when Jack R. Lousma, a former astronaut, won the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Carl Levin, a liberal Democrat. Mr. Lousma, a conservative, defeated former Representative James Dunn in the Republican primary, 334,717 votes to 200,079, for a margin of 63 percent to 37 percent. Mr. Lousma, who favors a constitutional ammendment against abortion and ran with the approval of the conservatives who now dominate Michigan's Republican Party, will contest Mr. Levin in a state that has generally elected moderate candidates. One of the leaders of the Republican conservatives, Richard Headlee, was soundly defeated by James J. Blanchard, a moderate, for the governorship in 1982.

headline.main: FEMALE SOVIET ASTRONAUT SAYS THAT WOMEN HAVE A PLACE IN SPACE

results.snippet: When Svetlana Savitskaya crawled out of the hatch of a Soviet space station last month to become the first woman to walk in space, she said today, her commander ''gallantly'' floated aside to give her his place. That gesture to her womanhood...
results.lead_paragraph: When Svetlana Savitskaya crawled out of the hatch of a Soviet space station last month to become the first woman to walk in space, she said today, her commander ''gallantly'' floated aside to give her his place. That gesture to her womanhood seemed to be one of the few the 36-year- old test pilot was willing to accept. At a news conference and a series of talks with reporters since her return, Miss Savitskaya made it clear she believed women should receive no special treatment in space. Appearing slightly irritated by frequent references to the pleasant atmosphere a woman brings to a space station, she said: ''We do not go into space to improve the mood of the crew. Women go into space because they measure up to the job. They can do it.''

headline.main: THE POWER OF POLITICAL CONSULANTS Ron Suskind, who is on the staff of The New York Times, has worked as a political consultant and a campaign manager in Connecticut and Virginia. By Ron Suskind I'VE GOT THIS SENATOR in his office,'' says Robert Goodman, ''and I'm shooting for three hours.'' The 55-year-old media consultant leans over the dinner table in a Maryland restaurant, sharing the events of his day. As he talks, his taut, wiry body begins to vibrate, hands waving, voice rising with the measured beat of a theatrical entertainer. ''I fire questions at him. I berate him. I say, 'Don't give me that stuff. Answer the question. Tell me what you feel.' The whole time, he's on camera. I've never brought the camera in this close. Finally he forgets it's there. He's sweating, getting mad, tie loosened, vulnerable.''

results.snippet: There is no script to the television commercial Goodman is describing, just the lights and cameras and the consultant peppering the candidate with questions. The goal of the advertisements is to change the voters' perception of an already...
results.lead_paragraph: There is no script to the television commercial Goodman is describing, just the lights and cameras and the consultant peppering the candidate with questions. The goal of the advertisements is to change the voters' perception of an already well-known public figure, and Goodman wants his subject - in this case, Senator Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa - with his defenses down. ''That works,'' he says. ''The voters have heard about this person, or seen him from a distance, but now they're close. Here's who he really is. Voters are saying, 'Hey, I didn't know him before.' '' Goodman is among the masters of political imagery, one of a handful of high-priced, much-sought-after experts who have spent the last decade remaking the political landscape. Media consultants design and produce all their clients' advertising - print and radio as well as television - and often decide where and when it will appear. They set themes for their candidates, raise funds and mobilize networks of longtime friends and allies to work in the campaigns.

results.snippet: DOG DAYS Never mind the horoscope creatures, August is when the dog days afflict New York. But a dog's life is not always something to be shuddered at, as the current exhibit, through Aug. 31, at the Dog Museum of America, 51 Madison Avenue, at...
results.lead_paragraph: DOG DAYS Never mind the horoscope creatures, August is when the dog days afflict New York. But a dog's life is not always something to be shuddered at, as the current exhibit, through Aug. 31, at the Dog Museum of America, 51 Madison Avenue, at 27th Street (696- 8350), illustrates. ''Pampered Pets'' is more about putting on the dog than about documenting a poor canine condition. It's a cool summer show that testifies to the worship of man's (and woman's) best friend, to the most cloying and sycophantic degree. There is a virtual fashion show of raincoats, galoshes, blue jeans, shirts, mink coats, tuxedo and topper, even an astronaut outfit, all designed for the dog, both today's dog and yesteryear's dog. There are dog collars of gold and of silver studded with gold. You can see pictures of dog grooming and trimming, arts that were developed in the 1600's and gave poodles top-knots and other odd headdresses and body language; dog barbers have been a part of the scene these many centuries.

results.snippet: Stepping up his attacks on Walter F. Mondale, President Reagan charged today that the Democratic Presidential nominee's ''knee-jerk'' policies would hurt taxpayers, farmers and consumers and return America to the ''despairing'' days of President...
results.lead_paragraph: Stepping up his attacks on Walter F. Mondale, President Reagan charged today that the Democratic Presidential nominee's ''knee-jerk'' policies would hurt taxpayers, farmers and consumers and return America to the ''despairing'' days of President Carter. At a ''community forum'' here in the farmlands of central Illinois, Mr. Reagan said Mr. Mondale's support of ''domestic content'' legislation requiring automobiles to have American-made parts would raise the price of cars and ''destroy'' jobs as foreign countries countered with trade barriers on American farm products. He also attacked the former Vice President, as he did Sunday in Missouri, for supporting the curtailment of grain shipments to the Soviet Union in 1980 after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. Mr. Mondale, he said, failed to see that the partial embargo punished farmers, not the Russians. ''I guess it's difficult to see the world clearly when you're scrooched down behind American farmers,'' he said.

headline.main: MINING OF MOON MATERIALS SEEN AS KEY TO SPACE WORK

results.snippet: A panel of scientists and engineers reported today that it ''makes sense'' for future space operations to exploit materials found on the moon and in asteroids, rather than rely on materials from the earth.    The panel's oral recommendation to...
results.lead_paragraph: A panel of scientists and engineers reported today that it ''makes sense'' for future space operations to exploit materials found on the moon and in asteroids, rather than rely on materials from the earth. The panel's oral recommendation to officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to be followed by a written report, came after 10 weeks of debate. The panel members disagreed over whether a permanent moon base should be established to mine oxygen for rocket fuel. The panel was one of several sponsored by the space agency to study the future of space exploration. A second study group, which met in April at Los Alamos, N.M., says it will recommend in October that the United States establish a permanent moon base in the next decade. A NASA group is also studying the feasibility of a moon base.

results.snippet: It has now become a commonplace, among Republicans and even in the nonpartisan press, to refer to what is going on in Dallas as ''The Coronation.'' So far, of course, it is only a metaphor, a way of talking about Ronald Reagan's popularity. But...

byline.original: By Richard M. Moose and Margaret D. Moose ; Richard M. Moose, who was Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs in the Carter Administration, and his wife, Margaret Davis Moose, are lifelong Democrats

results.lead_paragraph: It has now become a commonplace, among Republicans and even in the nonpartisan press, to refer to what is going on in Dallas as ''The Coronation.'' So far, of course, it is only a metaphor, a way of talking about Ronald Reagan's popularity. But perhaps we should reconsider. Perhaps the Republican National Convention should indeed nominate Ronald Reagan to be King of the United States. Mr. Reagan obviously possesses many of the attributes of the modern constitutional monarch. He can play virtually any role, and posing is second nature to him. As an actor, he takes easily to costumes. All he would

headline.main: MEN AND WOMEN IN FILM: A WAR ZONE UPDATE

results.snippet: It's been a long while since Hollywood abandoned its traditional model for relations between the sexes: the boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl, boy-gets-girl romance, followed by a middle-aged period devoted, happily or otherwise, to intense...
results.lead_paragraph: It's been a long while since Hollywood abandoned its traditional model for relations between the sexes: the boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl, boy-gets-girl romance, followed by a middle-aged period devoted, happily or otherwise, to intense domesticity. It's even been a while since, in the early 70's, changing perceptions of men's and women's societal roles left Hollywood increasingly unable to deal with romantic relationships at all. Hollywood's bewilderment in a period of vigorous social change brought about movies in which the lovers never quite fell in love, or the kinds of working-woman stories in which Jane Fonda (as she did in ''The China Syndrome'') came home alone to a pet turtle and an answering machine. The silence on the subject of sexual relations has been prolonged and uneasy. But it now appears to be drawing to a close.

results.snippet: Alan Shepard, during his 1971 moon walk, playfully hit some golf balls into space with a six-iron he had smuggled aboard the space capsule.     On Oct. 1, the first Canadian astronaut goes into space, and he won't forget his country's sports...

byline.original: By Jane Gross and Sam Goldaper

results.lead_paragraph: Alan Shepard, during his 1971 moon walk, playfully hit some golf balls into space with a six-iron he had smuggled aboard the space capsule. On Oct. 1, the first Canadian astronaut goes into space, and he won't forget his country's sports heritage.

headline.main: Diary Of A SpaceEnthusiast Had a real high time today. Went to a nearby school and announced that I've told NASA to choose a schoolteacher as the first civilian astronaut. Two million teachers will get a lift from that.

results.snippet: I've been a space fan ever since I saw ''The Right Stuff.'' It was so challenging that in my State of the Union speech last January, I called for NASA to build a manned space station, at a cost of $8 billion.
results.lead_paragraph: I've been a space fan ever since I saw ''The Right Stuff.'' It was so challenging that in my State of the Union speech last January, I called for NASA to build a manned space station, at a cost of $8 billion.

headline.main: SIX ASTRONAUTS SHARE LIFELONG LOVE OF FLIGHT AND A DREAM TO SEE THE STARS

results.snippet: Henry W. Hartsfield Jr.      Commander of Discovery has been an astronaut since 1966 space, an orbital tour in the shuttle Columbia in 1982 . . . has been enjoying flying since 1955, when he became an Air Force pilot after graduation from Auburn...
results.lead_paragraph: Henry W. Hartsfield Jr. Commander of Discovery has been an astronaut since 1966 space, an orbital tour in the shuttle Columbia in 1982 . . . has been enjoying flying since 1955, when he became an Air Force pilot after graduation from Auburn University in Alabama . . . remained in the service 22 years . . . born Nov. 21, 1933, in Birmingham, Ala. . . . graduate of test-pilot school at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., has logged more than 5,000 hours in variety of jet aircraft . . . served as test pilot instructor and in 1966 joined astronaut corps for Air Force Manned Orbiting Laboratory . . . shifted to NASA astronaut corps in 1969, where he worked at earthbound assignments and training and waited through the Apollo and Skylab projects without getting into orbit . . . with wife, Judy, has two grown daughters. Michael L. Coats He surprised no one when he became a pilot and then an astronaut . . . son of an Air Force bomber pilot, grew up with airplanes and decided that flying was for him . . . after graduating from the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis in 1968, became a fighter pilot and flew 315 combat missions in Vietnam . . . received 46 awards for his flying skills and heroism, including two Navy Distinguished Flying Crosses . . . has flown more than 3,500 hours in 22 different kinds of aircraft and is now a commander in the Navy . . . although pilot for the Discovery's first mission, he was making his first flight in space . . . born in Sacramento, Calif., 38 years ago, now lives in Riverside . . . earned a master's degree in administration of science and technology from George Washington University and a master's degree in aeronautical engineering from the Naval Postgraduate School at Monterey, Calif . . . joined astronaut corps in 1978 to train especially for the shuttle program . . . with wife, Diane, has two children.
